Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Activation functions and data types
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=W9mGKVJqj8uzS9GypME5i_IVt4tB8zRitz3X9lm6Vp7lmwKZj-09
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod
From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

Hi Ken,

On 18 February 2016 at 19:55, kstanley@... [neat]
<neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
> Interesting question, Colin.  I'm not sure about the best size for
> datatypes, but it's true that the y=min(0,x) function, called a ReLU,

FYI that should have been max(0,x) of course; my mistake.

> has become popular in gradient-based neural optimization (i.e. deep
> learning and backprop).  There are also a number of variations on that
> theme at Rectifier (neural networks) - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Noted.  I understand for x less than 0, y = 0.1x or similar is
commonplace because it maintains a gradient that can be followed.

> However, it's not yet clear or known whether this kind of activation
> function benefits neuroevolution.  It seems to help gradient methods by
> better preventing the gradient from being lost as it passes through many
> layers of a deep network,

I think it's basically the simplest way of providing a non-linearity
and any other downsides are balanced against much faster speed to
compute, which is a big deal on very large networks.

> Perhaps it could end up attractive simply because it's simpler to compute
> than something like a sigmoid,

That's what I'm thinking - a nice performance boost.


> but we'd first want to check to see if there are any implications to
> evolving networks of ReLUs versus sigmoids.

I'd like to try it out if I get chance. I was thinking of running a
well defined problem N times and plotting the distribution of clock
times (or generations, or evaluations) to find a solution. Do that for
sigmoid and ReLU and see if the distributions differ... and for a
range of different problems.

Regarding data types and precision, it was suggested to me that google
use weights values represented with as few as 8 bits in working
networks, i.e. already learned weights, but when learning they're
following potentially very small gradients, so they don't want to lose
those small gradients to lost precision.

For NEAT it's more about what is the the smallest step size we might
find useful, or rather, what what is the largest minimum step size for
which NEAT's solution finding ability is not affected. I'd like
revisit this question at least for double versus single precision
floats, ideally with a compiler switch in SharpNEAT so the end user
gets to choose the precision they want.


 - Colin
